summary: The case of Manlio Vendittelli v. Italy concerns an Italian national who lodged an application with the European Commission of Human Rights, alleging a breach of Article 6 para. 1 (right to a fair trial) and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 (protection of property) of the European Convention on Human Rights. The applicant claimed that his property rights were violated when the Italian authorities seized and sold his farm without providing him with a fair trial. The case was referred to the European Court of Human Rights, which found that the Italian authorities violated the applicant's right to a fair trial under Article 6 para. 1 and his protection of property under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1. The key points of the case are the lengthy and unfair criminal proceeding against the applicant, the repeated postponements of the trial, and the failure to release the applicant's property from sequestration despite the Court of Appeal's judgment. The relation between the facts, procedure, and legal arguments is that the lengthy and unfair criminal proceeding and the failure to release the property from sequestration violated the applicant's rights under Article 6 para. 1 and Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.
